newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Colombia's Samper hits back on drug issue at UN.
newsitem.headline: Colombia's Samper hits back on drug issue at UN.

text.p: Colombian President Ernesto Samper, facing fresh embarrassment in the war on drugs, launched an impassioned defence of himself and his country before the world community on Monday.
Just days after heroin was found stashed on his presidential jet, Samper urged the 185-nation U.N. General Assembly in a speech to set up a "grand alliance" to fight the scourge of drugs.
"Colombia wants to be part of the solution," Samper said. "We do not want to continue to be demonised when, in fact, we are all victims."
Samper has endured repeated calls for his resignation and the humiliation of seeing his country decertified as a partner of the United States in its war against drugs.
Colombia is the world's largest exporter of cocaine, a multibillion-dollar business run by powerful drug cartels. Thousands have died in drug-related violence in Colombia.
Washington has been concerned by charges that Samper personally approved the use of millions of dollars in drug money to finance his 1994 electoral campaign.
Samper used his speech to the United Nations to hit back at his critics, although he did not attack the United States or any other country by name.
"We have been the nation that has suffered the most, invested the most and paid the highest economic and social price in this war against criminal drug organisations," Samper said.

He said 20,000 Colombians had died as a result of drug wars over the past decade and noted that he too had been scarred, since he still carries four of the 11 bullets fired at him by right-wing hitmen linked to the drug trade in March 1989.
Giving thanks to God for his own survival, he said the smuggling of heroin onto the presidential plane was a failed plot to undermine the Colombian government.
"I am here today, before this world assembly, because nobody will stop me from making Colombia's proposal to fight the global criminal drug organisations," Samper said.

He gave few concrete details of how a global alliance to fight drugs should work, but said unilateral intervention in the affairs of others or judgmental attitudes should be left aside -- an oblique reference to U.S. criticism of Colombia.
There should be economic incentives for countries to replace drugs with other crops and tighter controls on money laundering in industrialised countries, he said.
"You cannot let all the weight of fighting drugs fall on the producer countries, which are the weakest link in the chain," he added.
Colombian radio said on Monday Samper would issue a statement after his speech, expressing tentative support for efforts to lift his country's ban on the extradition of drug lords.
There was no immediate sign of such a statement, and no one was available for comment at the Colombian mission to the United Nations.

As president Samper was humiliated when Washington revoked his U.S. visa in July because of allegations that he was linked to drug traffickers and as a sign of Washington's displeasure over a move by Colombia's Congress to clear him of drug corruption charges a month earlier.
The travel restriction does not apply to visits to U.N. headquarters, which is international territory.
Eleven members of the Colombian Air Force, including several officers, have been arrested in connection with the heroin found aboard Samper's presidential jet.
More than eight pounds (3.7 kg) of heroin was discovered aboard the Boeing 707 on Friday night as it was being readied at a military air base on the outskirts of Bogota for the flight to New York.
